turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Zee.

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: Jesse. What are you thinking? There are bounty hunters and lawmen all over this county!

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: I had to see you. I'm getting married.

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: She's the most wonderful woman in the world. Can't get her out of my mind.

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: That's... wonderful. It's just... I thought...

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: She's beautiful. Smart. And has the biggest... buck teeth in all of Missouri.

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: I would never have imagined us in a place like this.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: That's why I picked it. We can start a whole new life down here.

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: Are you going to be happy here, Mr. James? Without all that excitement?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: I've got you. You keep me busy. I figure we'll get over to the hotel... get checked in, cleaned up... then I'd like to do something I've been thinking about for a long time.

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: Now wait a minute. There are certain things that have to wait until after the wedding.

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: Hmm.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: "Hmm" what?

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: "But the life of the James Gang wasn't all robbing and shooting and killing, for these young Missouri bucks had a taste for the ladies... especially the handsome and charismatic Jesse James."

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: I beg your pardon?

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: "Blazing Guns of the West. True Stories of Jesse James." Only a dime in the hotel lobby.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Let me see that.

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: Oh, I'm not finished.  "When he sauntered into a saloon, his spurs jangling and his pockets full of gold, the ladies flocked around him like flies to a candied apple."  As I said. Hmm.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Now, sweetie, y'all wouldn't go believing one of them silly dime novels, would you?

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: Jesse, have you ever noticed that when you're trying to charm your way out of trouble, your accent gets all farm boy?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Aw, shucks, ma'am...

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: Stop it. This is just sad.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Swimming. Swimming is good.

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: Don't turn around.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: If you don't see it, it's not real...

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: You get arrested again, I'll kill you.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Yes ma'am.

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: I can't believe I had to blow up a train for you.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: You are a hell of a woman.

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: Don't swear.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Yes ma'am.

turns.speaker: ZEE
turns.text: Tennessee?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: I'll explain on the way.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: We're moving you tomorrow.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: But I like the presidential suite.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Oh, it's a similar room. But the hotel is in Washington D.C. You're not going to get a fair trial down here, in front of a jury of Jesse James sympathizers.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: So I'll get a fair trial in front of a jury bought off by Thaddeus Rains?

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: That's the idea.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Did you order our houses burned down?

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Not that day. I am guilty of many things, but that was Mr. Thaddeus Rains and Parker, that day.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: You almost ended my career before it began.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Pity.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: How did you spot the ambush in Torrell?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Last February?

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Mmm.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: You had all those cattle there, so I'd think the extra men were in town from the cattle drive?

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: The cows had a brand from a farm just five miles out of town.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Damn.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Almost got me in Billings. I saw you there, shooting at me.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: I went myself to oversee the operation. Didn't help much.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: No, that one was close. A couple fellas quit after that one.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Oh. That's nice to know.  We're going to hang you, you know.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: I figured.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Was it worth it?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Should have just killed Thaddeus Rains and been done with it.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: That's what I would have done.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: I'm not hanged yet.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: You cocky little bastard.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Ahh, you'll miss me.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: No, I'll hang you.  But I may miss you just a bit.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: That was for my Ma. Now this is for everybody else.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: He's too important, James.  They'll set the army on you. You and your wife.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: The railroad has no business in Tennessee. Therefore I have no interest in the state of Tennessee.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: I'd just as soon kill you, Jesse James. But chasing you takes up too much of my time.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Fair enough.

turns.speaker: PASTOR
turns.text: This is unusual. Most of our marriages are members of the congregation.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: You don't think God'll mind, do you?

turns.speaker: PASTOR
turns.text: The Lord is remarkably tolerant of the charitable.  "Jesse Woodson James." Jesse James? The Jesse James?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: I could have lied I suppose, but I want this marriage to be legal. I just want you to know, I'm trying to start a new life here. I'm depending on your...

turns.speaker: PASTOR
turns.text: Discretion? Sir, I am a man of the cloth.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: PASTOR
turns.text: Who needs to repair a leaky church roof.

turns.speaker: PASTOR
turns.text: Now let's have a drink.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Right here in church?

turns.speaker: PASTOR
turns.text: Communion.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: And you're too young.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I'm the same age you were when you went off to war.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: And the same age Web was. No.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I like that.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You okay, Jesse?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Yeah. Hey, are you drinking whisky? You're too young to be drinking whisky.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Not too young to shoot a man, not to young to drink.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: I guess so.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I was always jealous Web Mimms got to go off and fight with you and Cole. Now it's my turn.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: Jim, you been with a girl yet?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Tonight? Why, I'm just getting ready to turn on the Younger charm.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well, not exactly.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: You been with a girl ever?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Hell yeah! I been with...  Uh, not exactly. It's just, I don't want to get one of these paid ladies, you know?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: I think so.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You and Frank and Cole, and even Bob, get all these girls because you're good looking and famous. You don't have to pay. They just look at me like I'm the baby brother.  Don't tell anyone, okay Jesse?

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: I swear.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Tell you something else.  I can't drink that good neither. I'm going to go outside and throw up.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: You do that.

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: What about that Rock Island bastard?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: It's his money.  He's putting up the payroll out of his own fortune. You do want to hurt Thaddeus Rains, don't you Jesse?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: ... too young for whisky...

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: This time we'll make an exception.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Jesse, you explain to Lyla. My girl, you know, from that time...

turns.speaker: JESSE
turns.text: You're gonna tell her when you're resting up in bed with her, Jimmy.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Why, yeah.

turns.speaker: LYLA
turns.text: I hope you don't mind, Jesse James told me your name.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Oh, you were talking to Jesse.

turns.speaker: LYLA
turns.text: Yes, but just so I could find out who you were.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: LYLA
turns.text: I hope I'm not being too forward.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Not at all.

turns.speaker: LYLA
turns.text: I just though you were awful cute.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Thank you, Miss -- ?

turns.speaker: LYLA
turns.text: Lyla Devereux.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Gosh, that's a pretty name. Buy you a drink?

turns.speaker: LYLA
turns.text: Could we go upstairs and talk? It's so loud down here.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Why don't we get a bottle of sherry to sip while we talk?

turns.speaker: LYLA
turns.text: That is so gentlemanly of you.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Devereux. My brother Cole dated a European girl once.

turns.speaker: LYLA
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Don't talk about it much, though.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Well, this land is about to be condemned.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: I'm doing you folks a favor --

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: Relax, Alan. The Army has this all in hand. And Mr. Thaddeus Rains will be very pleased with this news. Nothing like a hanging to motivate the populace to relocate.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: It's not my job to relax. I've put men facing out both ways down Main Street, so nobody can ride in shooting. I've got a sharpshooter up on the water tower just in case.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: My professional opinion is that you have managed to piss off the wrong bunch of farm boys this time.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: They had to be dealt with!

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: By burning down their homes?

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: How can that be?

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: They donate money to farmers, to churches. Rumor has it they gave the sharecroppers of Maddox so much money they were able to build a school.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: There's only four of them...

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Move you fools!

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: Mr. Thaddeus Rains, sir, it is a pleasure to have you join us in the field.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: And it is my pleasure to be here.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: Really!

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: NO! It is NOT my pleasure to have to leave my board room to come to this godforsaken piece of dirt to discover why in the name of all that is holy you cannot seem to evict a few simple farmers from their PATHETIC LITTLE MUDHOLES so that I may build the GREATEST railroad that this country has ever seen!

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: I can completely understand your distress, sir.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: Parker, tell me what's going on so I can return as quickly as possible to Boston and my whores and cigars, not necessarily in that order.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: Two weeks ago, we managed to arrange to have the Army hang one of the local farmers.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: Unfortunately not, sir. A gang of local thugs managed to rescue him from the gallows. Not only has this inspired resistance from the other farmers, the redoubtable Mr. Alan Pinkerton was seriously injured during the incident.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: Leaving you in charge of operations until he recovers.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: Just perfect.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: A further impediment is that the Army garrison has been ordered to move on from Liberty. We will no longer have that particular stick with which to threaten the farmers.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: You see the Army leaving and you see the loss of a tool. I see a power void to be filled. As we have the most power, we may move with impunity.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: I see. I'll get together four patrols of our detectives for action tonight.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: I'll teach these podunks what happens when they challenge the righteousness of progress.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: They exchanged fire with the Pinkerton Guards, killing several of them. Then they raided the payroll office and blew the tracks for half a mile.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: How much did they get from the safe?

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: Thirty-five thousand, sir. Coins and currency. And the delay from the miles of destroyed track --

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: I'll kill them for blowing up my railway!

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: To be precise, they didn't blow up the tracks.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: THEN WHO DID?!

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: We did.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: Your men knew the risks.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: What is going on here, man?

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: With my money!

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: We should go burn that school to the ground, sir!

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: The final route for the railroad is complete.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: I look forward to seeing it.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: Parker.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: What is that?

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: What, sir?

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: That.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: Oh, that. I'll let Jenkins explain.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: This is him.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: I remember you.

turns.speaker: PARKER
turns.text: How did you know?

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: Not such a menace now, is he, Pinkerton?

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: Look at this, Pinkerton! They got the payroll, and this damage will set construction back two months at least.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Not to mention my men who lost their lives.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: You wouldn't have done that?

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Oh no, I would have done that. But I would have made sure I killed them, too.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: I want them arrested and hanged!

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Would a jury around here convict their own? I think not. We're beginning an interesting game here, Mr. Rains.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: This is no game.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: I'm afraid our adversaries don't agree.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: "A Rock Island and Pacific Railroad depot was robbed two nights ago just outside St. Louis, Missouri. The brave and daring James-Younger Gang was heavily outnumbered by Pinkerton detectives, but the city lawmen were no match for the guns of the West."

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: It is a nice piece of writing.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: "The gang made off with thirty-five thousand dollars and also destroyed the Thaxton Switch construction, meaning that for a few months honest farmers will be able to sleep without fearing the railroad is coming to steal their land!"  Who wrote this!? I'll see him hanged every Tuesday for a month!

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Oh, that's the best part.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: It's early in the game yet, Mr. Rains. Jesse James and I are just learning how each other moves, feeling out each other's patterns.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: I'm losing millions of dollars and months of time while you play chess with these farmers!

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Hardly farmers. I've done some checking. All these were in the War. These men know sabotage, tactics, and have four years of bloody fighting experience behind them. They are disciplined, well-trained and have a charismatic leader. If I were to design the perfect outlaw band, this gang is what I would create.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: So you can't tell me anything?

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: It's going to be a long winter.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: Pinkerton. It's been eight months. I see robberies. I see hold ups. But I do not see men on the end of nooses.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: All of the James Gang's encounters have been with local law enforcement who, quite frankly, are no match for this group's cunning.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: First of all: you, shut up.  Now, you've given me a thousand miles of railroad to cover. Every time the James Gang strikes, we shift a hundred detectives to that area. But there's just too much open land, too many riverbeds to ride, caves to hide in. This gang operates across four states, often riding a hundred miles between jobs.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: I can't believe this.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: And there are some towns in Missouri where James and his men can walk openly, as heroes.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Yes, that's the way to win the locals back to our side.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: I demand action.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: No, you demand results. They are not the same thing. And if you want results, you will let me do my job as I see fit. Unless of course,  You want this fool to saddle up and take another run at it?

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: Can't you tell me anything?

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: It's going to be a long spring.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: So he's won.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Every three months, the James Gang circles back to the vicinity of Liberty, Missouri. They always pull a job right before they return, probably to have extra money to give family and friends.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: In English, Pinkerton.

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: There are only four banks within that travel radius which they have not robbed.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: Can you put men at all four?

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: No need. I have another tool at my disposal which will narrow it down to one bank.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: What is that?

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Why, their intense hatred of you, of course.

turns.speaker: RAINS
turns.text: What the hell is that sound?

turns.speaker: PINKERTON
turns.text: Vengeance.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Listen, what are you doing tonight?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: What? Oh, I'm...busy.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Listen, you're dating Luis, he's in Arizona. You're fucking me, and we haven't made plans. What could you possibly be up to tonight?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Stop it. I'm...

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: On a lot of lithium?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Waiting for Luis to call me. He said he'd call tonight. Oh don't be difficult, Patrick.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: You should come have dinner with me. COURTNEY But-when?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Am I confused or were we talking about tonight?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Ummm . . yeah. Luis is calling me tonight. I need to be home for that.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Pumpkin?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Pumpkin you're dating an asshole.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Uh huh.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Pumpkin you're dating the biggest dickweed in New York.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: I know. Stop it.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Pumpkin, you're dating a tumbling, tumbling dickweed.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Patrick don't call me pumpkin anymore, okay? I have to go.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Courtney? Dinner?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: I can't.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I'm thinking Dorsia.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Dorsia's nice.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Nice?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: You like it there, don't you?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: The question is do you like it, Courtney? And will you blow off a fucking phone call from your sad excuse for a boyfriend to eat there tonight.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Okay. Yeah. What time?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Eight?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Pick me up?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Sounds like I'll have to. Don't fall asleep, okay? Wear something fabulous. Dorsia, remember?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: A facial at Elizabeth Arden, which was really relaxing, then to the Pottery Bam where I bought this silver muffin dish.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Is that Donald Trump's car?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Oh God, Patrick. Shut up.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: You know, Courtney, you should take some more lithium. Or have a Diet Coke. Some caffeine might get you out of this slump.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: I just want to have a child. Just...two... perfect...children...

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: J&B. Straight.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Champagne on the rocks. Oh-could I have that with a twist? She starts to sink back in her chair and Bateman leans over and pulls her back up.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Are we here?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: This is Dorsia?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Yes, dear.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Courtney, you're going to have the peanut butter soup with smoked duck and mashed squash. New York magazine called it a 'playful but mysterious little dish." You'll love it. And then...the red snapper with violets and pine nuts. I think that'll follow nicely.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Mmmm...thanks, Patrick.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Luis is a despicable twit.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Yes, Luis is a despicable twit. I hate him.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: No, you idiot. I said "Is it a receptacle tip?" Not, is Luis a despicable twit. Is it a receptacle tip? Get off me.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Is it a what?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Pull out.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I'm ignoring you.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Pull out, goddamnit!

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: What do you want, Courtney?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: It's a plain end. I think.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Turn the light on.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Oh Jesus. I'm going home.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Patrick. Turn on the Light. He turns on the light.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: It's a plain end, see? So?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Take it off.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Because you have to leave half an inch at the tip   to catch the force of the ejaculate! BATEMAN I'm getting out of here. Where's your lithium?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Oh Christ, this really isn't worth it. And see, Courtney, it's there for what? Huh? Tell us.  Why is it pulled down half an inch? So it can catch the force of the ejaculate!

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Well, it's not a turn-on for me. I have a promotion coming to me. I don't want to get AIDS.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: See? Happy? You dumb bitch? Are you happy, you dumb bitch?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Oh God, just get it over with.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Will you call me before Thanksgiving?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: What are you doing tonight?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Dinner at the River Cafe. Au Bar afterwards, maybe.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: That's nice.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: You and...Luis?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: We were supposed to have dinner at Tad and Maura's, but-you know how Luis is...

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I never knew you smoked.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: You never noticed.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Listen...Patrick. Can we talk?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: You look marvelous. There's nothing to say. You're going to marry Luis. Next week, no Less.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Isn't that special?  Patrick?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Yes, Courtney?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Patrick?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I haven't seen you around here.

turns.speaker: CHRISTIE
turns.text: You just haven't been looking.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Would you like to see my apartment?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Do you want to come to my apartment or not?

turns.speaker: CHRISTIE
turns.text: I'm not supposed to.  But I can make an exception.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Do you take American Express?

turns.speaker: CHRISTIE
turns.text: You have a really nice place here...Paul. How much did you pay for it?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Actually, that's none of your business, Christie, hut I can assure you it certainly wasn't cheap.

turns.speaker: CHRISTIE
turns.text: I'm not so sure about this. I had to go to Emergency after last time...

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Oh this won't be anything like last time, I promise.

turns.speaker: CHRISTIE
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Nothing like last time, promise.

turns.speaker: CHRISTIE
turns.text: Alright.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: So, you're looking great, how have you been?

turns.speaker: CHRISTIE
turns.text: Well, I actually might need a little surgery after last time.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: CHRISTIE
turns.text: My friend told me I should maybe even get a lawyer.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Oh, lawyers are so complicated-don't do that. Here.

turns.speaker: CHRISTIE
turns.text: This is nicer than your other apartment.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: It's not that nice.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Marzipan. Pink tents. Hundreds, thousands of roses. Photographers. Annie Leibovitz. We'll get Annie Leibovitz. And we'll hire someone to videotape. Patrick, we should do it.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Do...what.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Get married. Have a wedding.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Evelyn?

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Yes, darling?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Is your Evian spiked?

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: We should do it.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: No-I can't take the time off work.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Your father practically owns the company. You can do anything you like, silly.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I don't want to talk about it.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Well, you hate that job anyway. Why don't you just quit? You don't have to work.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Because I...want...to...fit...in.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Pat, this is my cousin Vanden and her boyfriend Stash. He's an artist.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Hi. Pat Bateman.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Why don t you just go for Price?

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Oh God, Patrick. Why Price? Price?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: He's rich.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Everybody's rich.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: He's good-looking.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Everybody's good-looking, Patrick.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: He has a great body

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Everybody has a great body now.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Are you using minoxidil?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: No. I'm not. Why should I ?

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Your hairline looks like it's receding.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: It's not.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: I want a firm commitment.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I think, Evelyn, that we've...lost touch.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Why? What's wrong?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: My need to engage in homicidal behavior on a massive scale cannot be, um, corrected, but I have no other way to fulfill my needs.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: We need to talk.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Talk about what, Patrick? What is there to talk about?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: It's over, Evelyn. It's all over

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Touchy, touchy. I'm sorry I brought the wedding up. Let's just avoid the issue, alright? Now, are we having coffee?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I'm fucking serious. It's fucking over. Us. This is no joke. I don't think we should see each other anymore.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: But your friends are my friends. My friends are your friends. I don't think it would work.  You have a little something on your upper lip.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I know that your friends are my friends. I've thought about that. You can have them.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: You're really serious, aren't you?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Yes, I am.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: But what about the past? Our past?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: We never really shared one.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: You're inhuman.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I'm...in touch with humanity. Evelyn, I'm sorry.  You're just not terribly important to me.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: No, no, no.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I know my behavior is...erratic sometimes.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: If you really want to do something for me, you can stop making this scene right now.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Oh God, I can't believe this.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I'm leaving now. I've assessed the situation and I'm going.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I'm just leaving.

turns.speaker: EVELYN
turns.text: But where?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I have to return some videotapes.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: You'll notice that my friends and I all look and behave in a remarkably similar fashion, but there are subtle differences between us. McDermott is the biggest asshole. Van Patten is the yes man. Price is the most wired. I'm the best looking. We all have light tans. Right now I'm in a bad mood because this is not a good table, and Van Patten keeps asking dumb, obvious questions about how to dress .

turns.speaker: VAN PATTEN
turns.text: What are the rules for a sweater vest?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Picked them up from the printers yesterday

turns.speaker: VAN PATTEN
turns.text: Good coloring.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: That's bone. And the lettering is something called Silian Rail.

turns.speaker: VAN PATTEN
turns.text: Eggshell with Romalian type.  What do you think?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Nice.

turns.speaker: VAN PATTEN
turns.text: But Laurie Kennedy is a total hardbody. What do you think, Bateman?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I know her. I knew her.

turns.speaker: VAN PATTEN
turns.text: Because he dated her.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: How did you guess?

turns.speaker: VAN PATTEN
turns.text: Girls dig Bateman. He's CQ. You're total CQ, Bateman.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Thanks, guy, but...she's got a lousy personality.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Do you know what Ed Gein said about women?

turns.speaker: VAN PATTEN
turns.text: Ed Gein? Maitre d' at Canal Bar?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: No, serial killer, Wisconsin in the fifties. He was an interesting guy.

turns.speaker: VAN PATTEN
turns.text: Listen, what about dinner?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Is that all you ever have to contribute, Van Patten? "What about fucking dinner?"

turns.speaker: MRS. WOLFE
turns.text: Are you my two o'clock?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MRS. WOLFE
turns.text: Can I help you?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I'm looking for...Paul Owen's...place.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Doesn't he live here?

turns.speaker: MRS. WOLFE
turns.text: No, he doesn't.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Are you sure?

turns.speaker: MRS. WOLFE
turns.text: You saw the ad in the Times?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: No. Yes. I mean yes, I did. In the Times. But... doesn't Paul Owen still live here?

turns.speaker: MRS. WOLFE
turns.text: There was no ad in the Times.

turns.speaker: MRS. WOLFE
turns.text: I think you should go now.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: But I think...I want to know what happened here.

turns.speaker: MRS. WOLFE
turns.text: Don't make any trouble. Please. I suggest you go.

turns.speaker: MRS. WOLFE
turns.text: Don't come back.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I won't...don't worry.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Excuse me, gentlemen. Right back. He approaches Carnes cautiously.

turns.speaker: CARNES
turns.text: Face it-the Japanese will own most of this country by the end of the '90s.

turns.speaker: CARNES
turns.text: Jesus, Davis. Yes. That was hilarious. That was you, wasn't it?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Yes, naturally.

turns.speaker: CARNES
turns.text: Bateman killing Owen and the escort girls? Oh that s fabulous. That's rich...
